description.narrative: Ghana is one of West Africa’s most peaceful, stable and resilient multi-party democracies. The country has held seven successive peaceful and credible general elections with three smooth transfers of power.

comment.narrative: Mark and record 17,000 Ghana Police Service weapons 5 communities sensitised against violent extremism 2 political parties with capacity in conflict management and resolution 10 hotspots are sensitised on electoral violence 50 Ghana Armed Forces Junior Officers trained 20,000 reached on anti stigma on covid19 2000 women benefit from business information

In 2020 UNDP with support the National Commission for Small Arms and Light Weapons and the Ghana Police Service to mark and record over 10,000 weapons of the police in 11 regions in accordance with the international and sub regional instruments, such as the ECOWAS Convention on small arms and light weapons ,the United Nations Programme of Action (UNPoA),the International Tracing Instrument (ITI) and the Firearms Protocol (FP); to prevent further diversion of official police weapons which are sometimes used to commit crime. This has enhanced the weapons stockpile and inventory management of the Ghana Police Service
With support from UNDP; Civil society organizations, law enforcement agencies,the media and HIV service providers have improved knowledge and capacities to facilitate effective implementation of anti- stigma policies and strategies. Current frameworks such as the Anti stigma strategy, Ghana AIDS Commission (GAC) Act (938) and its legislative instrument (L.I. 2403) and the strategic plan to address barriers related to HIV and TB services ,have been developed to create the enabling environment for the uptake of HIV and TB services. However effective implementation and collaboration by all stakeholders would be crucial to ensure that no one is left behind. UNDP in partnership with Ghana AIDS Commission thus supported various engagements with 38 CSOs,19 (8M,11F) media personnel, 8 service providers to strengthen their capacities to understand prevailing anti stigma policies, strategies and laws and their roles in supporting effective implementation and monitoring of these provisions[
UNDP in partnership with Ghana Health Services (GHS) supported health promotion and COVID 19 risk communication to vulnerable populations in hard to reach areas including persons with disability, people living with HIV and the prisons. 21566 ( 9,729 M,11,837F) persons with disability including the visually impaired (3077 M,3732F), physically challenged (5162M 6131F) and hearing impaired(1490M 1974F) in 165 districts across the country have been empowered with relevant COVID 19 information in disability friendly formats (including braille and sign language) to prevent COVID 19 infection within their communities. They are therefore now able to protect themselves from COVID-19 infection Furthermore, capacities of prisons to prevent COVID-19 infection has been enhanced with the training of 380 (206M 174F) prison officials and wardens from 12 prison facilities across the country on relevant knowledge, skills and tools on COVID-19 prevention. They are therefore now able to ensure the protection of the rights of those incarcerated, so they are not left behind. In addition, a module on COVID 19 prevention in the prisons have been developed to support COVID 19 prevention education in the prisons. 5451(2079M, 3372F) persons living with HIV (PLHIV) have also been empowered with relevant information on hand hygiene, mask wearing, respiratory etiquette and treatment adherence during the COVID 19 pandemic. Community information centers in hard to reach areas in 15 regions across the country have reached a total of 530854 (255520M, 275334F) with targeted COVID 19 prevention information including information on hand hygiene, mask wearing [[E48]].
A web-based game on electoral laws, vigilantism and small arms regulations as part of measures to educate the youth who formed over 45% of the voter population in the 2020 general elections. The game was an innovative way of engaging and reaching out to many youth without the presence of officers on the ground. About 6700 people played the page within the first two weeks of its deployment.
Ghana Armed Forces Command and Staff College trained 48 officers; 38 women and 10 males in a two week training and gained the relevant knowledge and skills in leadership, analytical and communication skills of junior-level army officers to enable them perform command and staff functions and enhance their understanding and knowledge of military operations. This enabled them to acquire the skills required to facilitate their nomination for a UN deployment.
296 ( F 115, M 181) border community members have increased knowledge on the threats of violent extremism and how to prevent radicalisation. Building capacities and creating awareness on the threat of violent extremism in coastal West Africa is considered as one of the ways to preventing violent extremism.
capacity of 40 members made up of M31 and F9 of the National Democratic Congress has been strengthened to deal with internal party conflicts to prevent and manage conflicts.
UNDP through the multi-stakeholder peace and governance platform supported the youth in four (4) hotspots Cheriponi, Tain, Lower Manya Krobo and Odododiodio to undertake peace march and peace education with over 1000 (F 550, M 450) youth and women participating. Participants demonstrated their commitment to contribute to peaceful Ghana by using their platforms to engage their members to be tolerant of others.
UNDP Ghana in collaboration with the National Small Arms Commission, National Peace Council with support from German Government sensitized and improved the knowledge of community members particularly political party youth on the threats of the proliferation of smalls and vigilante activities in selected hotspot constituencies namely Cheriponi, Tain, Odododiodio, Sekyere Afram Plains and Yilo and Lower Manya Krobo. 390 (F128, M 262) benefitted directly from the sensitization.
strengthened digital and financial inclusion for up to 2,000 women in the northern.In partnership with Vodafone Ghana Fonndation , Access Bank and Harvest Foundation, UNDP trained up to 2000 women in using digital wallets for saving rather than metal boxes. The women are organized in groups.
Gender policy for NCCE National Peace Architecture with strengthened capacity

Supporting governance institutions to build progressive gender policies remains critical to bridging existing gender inequality gaps and facilitating effective mainstreaming of gender into the operations and administrative activities. In this regard, through support from UNDP which enabled them to develop a gender policy, the National Commission for Civic Education (NCCE) has a better ability to undertake comprehensive and systematic action to effect sustained behavioural and organizational change towards gender equality and equity. NCCE currently has a Gender policy developed, Action Plan for Policy Implementation drawn, staff capacity (80 women, 137 men) built and enhanced on Gender Policy. It also has a communication Strategy and a Manual on Gender Policy developed.
UNDP has contributed to the National Peace Council (NPC) being bonded and able to engage with partners and parties to conflict using collaborative leadership skills to help resolve conflicts. This is the result of capacity development on Transformational Leadership and Team Building for 23 (6 women and 17 men) staff and regional/district secretaries. This is in addition to enhancing the collaborative leadership and dialogue skills of 19 (7 women and 12 men) Board and national staff .

UNDP supported the Ghana Small Arms and Light Weapons Commission and the Ghana Police Service in marking a total of about 8000 police weapons in the Volta, Oti and Ashanti Regions. This has enhanced weapons stockpile and inventory management that complies with international standards for weapons marking in accordance with the International Small Arms Control Standards (ISACS), Stockpile Management of Weapons, Marking and Recordkeeping, Tracing Illicit Small Arms and Light Weapons.
UNDP supported NCCE to revive the IPDC’s in 10 regions and establish IPDC’s in the 6 new regions. The 683 members representing the National Commission for Civic Education (NCCE), the Electoral Commission (EC), Political Parties, the Youth, Security Agencies, District Assemblies, Chiefs, Traditional Authorities, Civil Society and Community Leaders have initiated plans to engage their communities in promoting a peaceful environment before, during and after elections .
In 2019 UNDP supported the Commission on Human Rights and Administrative Justice (CHRAJ) to engage 113 (47 Females, 66 Males) stakeholders on the link between corruption and human rights. Stakeholders were educated with practical methods on how to contribute towards the fight against corruption. Additionally, awareness was raised on the impact of corruption on some critical sectors such as education, health care, water and sanitation among others.
Following the 2012 Electoral petition, several electoral reforms were recommended including the improvement of the quality of training provided to electoral officers. To implement this recommendation, the EC in 2019 recruited only university graduates. With UNDP support and in collaboration with the Association of African Election Administration (AAEA)153 (77 men and 76 women) newly appointed Electoral Officers have increased knowledge on elections administration and on the electoral process as well as understanding of their roles, in the conduct of free and fair elections in Ghana. The skills acquired will enable the officers contribute to the Electoral Commission’s delivery of its mandate in supervising and conducting peaceful, transparent and credible elections.
UNDP supported the AA Bill Technical Committee to develop a communication and advocacy strategy to facilitate increasing awareness and galvanize support of key stakeholders at national and sub-national levels. The strategy also seeks to guide engagement of relevant committees, leadership of Parliament for speedy passage of the Affirmative Action Bill into law. This has enhanced efforts to accelerate progress on the passage of the Affirmative Action Bill . The legislation which will increase participation of women in decision making at all levels in Ghana has finally reached the stage for Cabinet approval
UNDP supported the set up of a Regional Advocacy and Dissemination Team, a multidisciplinary advocacy teams comprising of health workers, CSO, PLHIV and Ghana AIDS Commission (GAC). UNDP supported capacity strengthening trainings for 26 representatives (12 females,14 males) from the regional advocacy teams, as well as 35 officers (15 females,20 males) from the Commission on Human Rights and Administrative Justice have led to greater understanding and appreciation of the current policy and legal regime for reducing HIV related stigma and discrimination in Ghana and how they can effectively support their implementation
UNDP provided support to the Ghana Anti-corruption Coalition (GACC) and the Commission on Human Rights and Administrative Justice (CHRAJ) in their engagements aimed at increasing the knowledge of youth on corruption and to brainstorm possible innovative Anti-Corruption actions they can implement targeting their communities and their peers. 321 youth (205 male & 116 female) from tertiary, senior high school and other youth groups from Accra and Kumasi committed to the fight against corruption with improved knowledge of the adverse effects’ corruption has on the socio-economic development of Ghana and the role they can play in addressing it.
